newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST - Fed may tighten, Aug jobs data key - survey.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Fed may tighten, Aug jobs data key - survey.

text.p: While a slim majority of U.S. experts expect an interest rate hike later this month, they still view Friday's jobs data as the key factor in any near term move by the central bank, according to a Reuters poll.

Thirteen of 30 economists surveyed on Tuesday predicted a 25-basis point hike in the federal funds rate at the September 24 Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting, while three expected a 50-basis point jump.
A stream of robust economic data has prompted experts to revise their forecasts from two weeks ago, when only three of 29 economists called for a September 24 tightening.
Economists who forecast a tightening said the rate of U.S. economic growth remained more vigorous than the Fed had hoped, which could lead to a tightening even before the next meeting.

"The question here is not whether" the Fed will tighten, contended Michael Strauss, executive vice president and chief economist at Yamaichi International (America) Inc. "The question is could Friday's number be strong enough" to prompt them to tighten on Friday, ahead of the meeting.

Last week, U.S. consumer confidence rose to its highest level in more than six years, second-quarter Gross Domestic Product registered the fastest growth rate in two years and July single-family home sales recorded the largest increase since February.

Economists polled last week projected the payrolls report would show 244,000 new jobs were added in August, compared to 193,000 in July. They said the central bank could feel pressure to raise rates in September if the payroll employment number comes in higher than expected, average hourly earnings show a significant increase and the unemployment rate dips.
"The recent data have been so strong and pointing to higher signs of inflationary pressure," said Dan Seto, an economist at The Nikko Securities Co International Inc.
He said the strength at this time could lead to nervousness among bond investors, adding that "a large increase in wages would translate into a much worse inflationary scare."

Although 16 of 30 economists polled expect a Fed tightening, 10 did not see a move before the upcoming meeting. Three, however, did expect a 25-basis-point increase by the November 13 FOMC gathering, and one predicted a move in 1997.
None of the respondents forecast an easing of credit.
Philip Braverman, chief economist at DKB Securities Inc, said the Fed will probably not move, especially before November's presidential elections.
With the November 5 presidential election looming, the central bank will act with extra prudence, he said. "The last thing the Fed wants to do is firm and have egg on their face."
Full results of the survey follow.
